# The benefits of hiring candidates with international experience

[Home](http://hrnews.co.uk) » [HR News](http://hrnews.co.uk/category/hr-news/)
» The benefits of hiring candidates with international experience

Posted on Jul 16, 2019

Whether it’s a full-on overseas posting, or a gap year in Singapore - the
benefits of hiring staff members that have had the opportunity to learn and
understand new cultures - especially from a business perspective,are
plentiful.

![](http://hrnews.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2017/11/plane-1.png)

Businesses that look to higher employees with transnational experience will
often do so because they want to tap into specific skills sets that can be
transferred into the workplace.

Whether it’s the ability to dedicate time to learning a new language, dealing
with customers who possess opposing cultural views, or feeling comfortable
operating in an environment that differs to the status quo - these skill sets
are highly beneficial to an employer.  

This is especially true for employers that are looking to take on graduate
candidates that have had international exposure. This viewpoint was supported
in a 2017-published study by QS Global Employer, which found that 6 out of 10
businesses would give a graduate candidate extra credit for exposing
themselves to a foreign market.

This appetite to gain international experience was highlighted in a recent
PwCreport, which estimates that the number of transnational postings will
increase by 50% in the next decade.

Personal growth  
Although somewhat of a cliche, the processing of 'finding oneself' on foreigns
oil can allow employees to assess their underlying strengths and weaknesses.In
terms of personal growth, an international placement can also give employees
the opportunity to evaluate their long-term goals and ambitions, and thus,
have a clear route of progression in mind.

  
This is highly beneficial from a human resource perspective, as employers can
ensure they are hiring someone has their specific career path mapped out. On
the contrary, hiring somebody without a clear career route in mind is likely
to result in the employee looking elsewhere once they realise the role isn’t
for them.

**Graduates thatstudied abroad also offer value**  
While international experience in a real-world business setting is desired,
employers are also keen to take on workers that chose to study abroad. Whether
it's Amsterdam, Lausanne, Paris or Zurich - student placements in [cultural
cities](https://oxfordsummercourses.com/articles/most-cultural-student-
cities/) offers businesses a number of key benefits.

  
Not only does it demonstrate that the individual was willing to live in a new
culture and spend the required time to learn a language, but it also
illustrates that they are capable to succeed in an environment that falls
outside of their natural comfort zone.

  
These highly transferrable skills are something that would benefit businesses
tremendously in a globalized world that is getting smaller.

# 4/5 of employers have been ‘ghosted’ by potential recruits

[Home](http://hrnews.co.uk) » [HR News](http://hrnews.co.uk/category/hr-news/)
» 4/5 of employers have been ‘ghosted’ by potential recruits

Posted on Aug 28, 2019

Four fifths (84%) of UK employers have experienced a candidate ‘ghosting’ them
part way through a recruitment process, according to a new survey by London
law firm, Joelson. ‘Ghosting’ is a relatively new phenomenon in which a
candidate disappears midway through a recruitment process, leaving the
employer with a headache in terms of having fewer candidates left or even
having to restart the process from scratch. A third of firms surveyed (31%)
estimated the cost per candidate ghosting them to be somewhere between £2000
and £5000.

![](http://hrnews.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/cv.jpg)

The survey – _Ghosting: The New Recruitment Trend_ , is based on the responses
from 100 HR professionals and management level staff-members who regularly
conduct interviews. The survey collected responses on ‘ghosting’ in the
recruitment process, and during employment, whereby employees fail to return
to work without any formal resignation or explanation.

**David Greenhalgh, Employment Partner at Joelson says:**

> ”Ghosting has become endemic for employers, costing businesses precious time
> and money. While there is no legal protection against ghosting, employers
> can attempt to limit risk by taking steps to screen candidates more
> thoroughly throughout the process, keep in touch more frequently between
> interviews, and use candidates’ stated preferred method of contact, such as
> WhatsApp rather than email. The high costs of ghosting means it is essential
> for businesses to do all they can to protect themselves against it.”  

**Other significant findings of the research include** :

  * 62% of respondents tried two or three times to contact applicants after they had gone silent 
  * 62% had experienced an employee failing to arrive on their first day of work despite having signed a contract 
  * 60% of respondents do not believe that candidate ghosting is a millennial trait 
  * 52% of companies have been ghosted by employees who just didn’t return to work without offering any resignation or explanation as to why they had left 

**Greenhalgh continues:**

> “Quite apart from the laws of common decency, ghosting by existing employees
> is particularly difficult for employers to deal with, as all avenues must be
> explored before they can officially consider the employee to have terminated
> their employment, in order to avoid the risk of possible claims.”

# The true cost of working from home

[Home](http://hrnews.co.uk) » [HR News](http://hrnews.co.uk/category/hr-news/)
» The true cost of working from home

Posted on Feb 11, 2020

_Working from home or sharing an office space - which one is right for you?_

![](http://hrnews.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/home.jpg)

It may seem like a great idea - rolling out of bed in your pyjamas and
switching on your laptop while you wait for the kettle to boil for your
morning cuppa.

And while working from home offers an ideal solution for many, some
professionals soon discover it isn’t all it’s cracked up to be - and that is
one of the reasons why the number of shared office spaces is on the rise.

According to a 2017 survey of more than 15,000 working adults, 43% of them
said they spent at least some time in the previous year working remotely, with
31% saying they worked from home four to five days each week. But 81% of these
workers admit there are downsides to working remotely.

This got us thinking - what is the true cost of working from home and is it
really worth it?

**Working from home - the good and the bad…**

Being home-based can be great as it provides workers with flexibility.
However, it can also be more costly than you think and can actually end up
eating into your very valuable time.

There are two types of homeworker - the **sole trader** who chooses their home
as their base and the **employee** who is allowed to work from home from time
to time.

**Independence, self-discipline and distractions**

Working from home allows you to be completely independent and you can
potentially get more work done as you aren't spending your time commuting.

But it also relies hugely on self-motivation and self-discipline and, if you
are easily distracted, you could find yourself getting a lot less done in
those eight hours - losing you time and money.

Being surrounded by your home comforts can make you feel a bit too relaxed and
less motivated too. Those afternoon naps may be too tempting to refuse, or you
may get caught up in home administration, watching television and doing
household chores instead.

**Investments, equipment and usage costs**

If you don't already own the right equipment, you will need to invest in
suitable technology, which could be costly. And, as you will be at home, you
will be using more water, gas and electricity than normal.

Unless you have a spare room in your home which can be turned into an office,
you will probably work from the sofa or dining room table.

While this may be great for a while, you need to think about the long-term
effects, as your back needs to be properly supported. Therefore, if you plan
on working from home, it will be a good idea to have a designated workspace,
complete with a desk and office chair.

**Working from home - the essentials**

We’ve put together a list of all of the things you will need if you’re going
to take the plunge and work from home (these are all approximate costs):

**Computer or laptop (£500 - £1,200) -** Your profession will depend on the
cost - the more technical your job, the more expensive your equipment will be.

**Monitor (£120)** - Again, this will depend on the type of job - if you work
across multiple projects, it will be a good idea to invest in a second
computer monitor.

**High-speed internet (£25 per month / £300 per year)** - It’s a must -
especially when working to client deadlines.

**Desk or workstation (£150)** - You will need a designated workspace with
enough space for all of your equipment.

**Office chair (£100) -** As you will be spending a great deal of your day
sitting down, it is important to get a chair that will provide comfort and
support.

**Telephone/work mobile (£40 per month / £480 per year)**  - Essential if your
work consists of speaking over the phone with colleagues and/or clients.

**IT software (minimum £9.40 per month / £112.80 per year) - **The level of IT
software you require will depend on your job, however there are certain pieces
of software that are essential.

**Printer (£60)** - All business owners and workers will need to use a printer
at some point, so it is important to have one at hand.

**Filing cabinet and storage (£100)** **  -** It is vital that you keep all
paperwork and documents safe and locked away in a filing cabinet to prevent
them getting lost or damaged.

**_Estimated total cost = £1,922.80_**

Costs will vary depending on your occupation and the equipment you require;
however it is worth noting that the initial costs can be very expensive.

**Productivity and working too much**

It may seem strange, as there are so many potential distractions when working
from home but there is a danger of it becoming a bit of a strain.

Because you’ll have a quieter environment and be avoiding the occasional
disruptions of working in an office, you may lose track of time and end up
working too much, clocking up too many hours, risking your work life blurring
into your home life.

This may leave you feeling as if you are always at work, causing you to feel
deflated, burnt out and as though there is no separation between working and
enjoying being at home.

**Lack of communication, networking and business opportunities**

Working from home can be rather lonely, with no physical human interaction or
communication. As you will be working individually a lot of the time, it can
also lead to less networking opportunities for your business.

You might become to feel out of the loop with the industry you work in. It is
hard to replicate the casual, spur-of-the-moment collaborations and
brainstorming sessions with colleagues which can have such a positive effect
on your attitude towards working.

**Co-working spaces: A modern alternative**

Although you may get the occasional interruptions from co-workers, working in
a serviced, [co-working office
space](https://www.searchofficespace.com/blog/20-of-the-best-coworking-spaces-
in-london/) can be extremely advantageous.

**Routine and structure**

Working from home may sound perfect, however it lacks one of the most
important things that sole traders and employees need - routine and structure.

Although people think they can be self-motivated and disciplined, they are
often not. Flexible co-working spaces are the ideal environment and provide
the perfect mixture of independence, self-discipline and routine.

Having a co-working space to go to means that you will arrive at a certain
time and leave eight hours later. Working too many hours in the day can have a
negative impact on your performance - having a designated place to work can
boost productivity and motivation.

**Feeling productive and motivated**

First of you all, you will be dressed in your working business attire which
immediately makes you feel more motivated and ready to take on the day.
Whereas if you worked from home, you may be tempted to stay in loungewear,
leaving you feeling sluggish.

Working in a shared office space also means you’ll be surrounded by other
motivated and productive professionals - this will have a positive impact on
you and your work.

**Costs and saving money**

Working in a shared office space may seem more expensive but it could actually
save you money.

All the equipment, technology, bills and maintenance are included in your
monthly rental charge, meaning there will be no surprise charges at the end of
each month. You are supplied with everything you need without having to go out
and buy it yourself.

**Access to professional work space**

You will have access to meeting rooms, desks and office space that you
wouldn't normally have. Creating a workspace at home could end up costing you
a lot more than sharing a flexible work space.

With meeting rooms always available, this allows for catching up with clients,
saving you from forking out for an external space if you were to work from
home.

**Networking and business opportunities**

Sharing an office space with other like-minded professionals can provide you
with endless networking opportunities which could lead to bigger, better
things for your business and even make you money in the long run. And you
could make lots of new friends!

Take a look at some of the best serviced office spaces available and start
your new adventure today.

# Revealed: Cities & industries with the WORST work-life balance

[Home](http://hrnews.co.uk) » [HR News](http://hrnews.co.uk/category/hr-news/)
» Revealed: Cities & industries with the WORST work-life balance

Posted on Mar 10, 2020

**A new report, which surveyed 1,000 small business owners** and sole traders
across the country has been carried out by financial experts, **Takepayments
Limited** , unveiling a snapshot of the small business landscape in the UK. It
uncovers key challenges for small businesses in 2020, including the work-life
balance of those in different cities and industries.

![](http://hrnews.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/city-of-london.png)

Below you can find a list of the **top cities & industries** that struggle to
maintain a healthy work-life balance. The data took in factors such as;

  * how they felt about their work-life balance 
  * If they do more than 48 hours in a working week (over the legal limit) 
  * If they take two days rest each week 
  * If they looked after their staff/colleague’s wellbeing 

**Cities with the WORST work-life balance**

**Position**|  **City**|  **% of people who struggle to maintain a work-life
balance**  
---|---|---  
**1.**|  Aberystwyth|  40%  
**2.**|  Liverpool|  38%  
**3.**|  Coventry|  30%  
**4.**|  Bristol|  20%  
**5.**|  Birmingham|  17%  
  
Just under half of the people who have a business in Aberystwyth have declared
that they struggle to maintain a healthy work-life balance. 40% of people here
also did not take their two-day rest periods in a working week.

In Liverpool, It was found that 32% of people who own a business worked more
than a 48-hour working week, which is **OVER** the legal limit for your health
and wellbeing, according to the citizen’s advice.

In Coventry, a staggering **70% of business owners** are putting their
colleagues' health first and making sure their checking in with their health
and wellbeing. However, 30% struggle to maintain their own work-life balance.

**It was also found that 1 in 6 do not take any rest days in the UK** when
running their own business and almost half (46%) are struggling to forward
plan for their business because of the current political landscape.

**Industries with the WORST work-life balance**

**Position**|  **Industry**  
---|---  
**1.        **|  Recruitment & HR  
**2.        **|  Public Services & Administration  
**3.        **|  Social Care  
**4.        **|  Teaching and Education  
**5.        **|  Transport and logistics  
**6.        **|  Publishing & Journalism  
**7.        **|  Retail  
  
Business Owners in Recruitment & HR are amongst the worst for their work-life
balance with half of those surveyed saying they do not feel they had a good
work-life balance from their work and personal life. Over a quarter (34%) said
that they are not having at least two days off in the week for a rest period.

Second to recruitment & HR was public services & administration with 15% of
business owners struggling to maintain their work-life balance. However, over
half (54%) say that they are making sure to support and look after their
colleagues and staff’s mental health.

Nearly half (48%) who run a business within transport and logistics are
finding they claim back some of their work-life balance by sticking to a 48
hour week, managing health with time limits on their day.  

For those in publishing and journalism, 40% have claimed they do not have at
least two days of rest (non-working) per week, adding potential pressure to
burning out after some time. Over a third (30%) do say they stick to a 48-hour
working week or less, however, to maintain some balance.

For those owning a business in retail, 28% are struggling to take at least two
rest days in the week, helping to support their staff and run the business.

Industry percentage of business owners struggling with to maintain a healthy
work-life balance:

  * Recruitment & HR (50%) 
  * Public Services & Administration (15%) 
  * Social Care (14%) 
  * Teaching and Education (13%) 
  * Transport and logistics (11%) 
  * Publishing & Journalism (10%) 
  * Retail (6%) 

**The full report including information on other topics such as finance can be
found here:** https://www.takepayments.com/small-business-challenges/

# The Top Five Reward Trends that shaped 2019

[Home](http://hrnews.co.uk) » [HR News](http://hrnews.co.uk/category/hr-news/)
» The Top Five Reward Trends that shaped 2019

Posted on Nov 26, 2019

Reward Management consultancy Paydata has captured insights into pay awards,
bonuses and employee turnover in the latest edition of their [UK Reward
Management Survey](https://www.paydata.co.uk/hr-hub/reports/uk-reward-
management-survey/the-top-five-reward-trends-of-2019/) . In addition, their
autumn survey has explored employer attitudes towards business planning around
Brexit, organisations’ approaches to managing mental health and wellbeing in
the workplace, and current activity around setting competitive benefits
packages.

![](http://hrnews.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/paydata.jpg)

138 HR Directors, Finance Directors and Reward/Compensation Specialists
provided their insights into practices affecting around 380,000 employees.

Here Paydata’s Director Tim Kellett outlines the five key developments
affecting reward professionals in the UK.

  1. **Business optimism wavers as Brexit remains an unknown**

Political turbulence persists, with another general election scheduled before
Christmas and the campaign trail in full swing. This has postponed a potential
‘no-deal’ Brexit and we note the effect this uncertainty is having on
businesses and the impact on their operations. Only half of organisations have
a plan in place to protect the business or identify potential opportunities,
whilst only six to eight per cent of businesses see Brexit as an opportunity
on any timescale.

Whilst business optimism had remained steady with 57 per cent of respondents
expecting revenues to increase in spring 2019, consistent with projections for
the last three years, our autumn survey has captured a notable decline in
business confidence to 31 per cent expecting increased revenues.

  * **Pay awards and out of cycle awards remain steady**

Up to three per cent pay increases remain most popular amongst respondents,
sustaining wage growth as it tracks just above inflation. The two most quoted
drivers for pay increases are external relativities and targeting high
performing individuals – putting a firm focus on recruiting and retaining the
right talent through competitive reward packages. Loyalty no longer translates
to automatically higher pay, with two thirds of organisations having to offer
new recruits salaries that conflict with those paid to existing employees.

We continue to monitor the role of out of cycle pay increases, as 75 per cent
cite market pressures as a key driving force behind their use. These types of
increases supplement steady pay awards as they bridge the gap between official
pay review figures and wider market pressures, most commonly accounting for up
to one per cent of annual pay bills.

  * **Recruitment challenges are acute for employers**

Over half of respondents (55 per cent) have experienced difficulty in
retaining people and anticipate ongoing retention difficulties. However, more
respondents revealed difficulties with recruiting people over the past 12
months, with 66 per cent facing challenges. 60 per cent also anticipate
difficulties in recruiting over the next 12 months.

Organisations believe that Brexit will have the biggest impact on skills and
labour shortages, with 33 per cent saying investment in this area will be
increased as a result of Brexit and 36 per cent saying it is too early to
tell. This is in contrast to half of organisations saying that investment in
other HR/Reward operations (pay review funding, project budgets and the
employment of young people) will remain the same.

  * **Employee benefits increasingly reflect employee values**

66 per cent have reviewed their benefits offering in 2019 and 82 per cent
expect to in 2020, demonstrating how keen organisations are to ensure they are
offering competitive benefits packages that reflect value in employees’ eyes –
a key recruitment and retention tool. The top three reported benefits are:

  1. Pension scheme (97 per cent)
  2. Life assurance (89 per cent)
  3. Employee assistance programme (86 per cent)

The fact that pensions consistently feature as the number one benefit is not
surprising in itself, as the government has put the onus onto the employer to
offer every employee access to a pension scheme through auto enrolment. This
means the decision regarding pensions comes down to how much the employer
should contribute. Employers should ensure that employees know their options
and the long-term value of the benefit. More creative benefits consistently
feature that relate to employee health and wellbeing. 70 per cent offer bike
to work schemes, 42 per cent offer gym memberships and 57 per cent offer
health check-ups, showing that many businesses are looking to support health
and wellbeing. This illustrates the different approaches organisations take
when it comes to defining wellbeing in the workplace.

  * **The role of the employer in employee mental health and wellbeing**

Overwhelmingly, employers are recognising their responsibility to support
employees with their wider wellbeing and specifically, their mental health. 83
per cent of respondents have policies and procedures in place to specifically
support mental health and wellbeing in the workplace. Just as employee
assistance programmes feature in the top benefits reported by companies, this
is also the top mental health and wellbeing initiative in the workplace. This
is followed by 92 per cent providing flexible working and 86 per cent offering
access to counselling services. It is important to note the opportunity for
mental health and wellbeing initiatives to work hand in hand and effect long-
term cultural awareness and change.

Respondents reported workplace stigma and perceptions as the top challenge to
managing mental health and wellbeing. Furthermore, return on investment was
frequently cited as a barrier to overcome when requesting resource in this
area; however, 82 per cent cited a lack of clarity over how to measure success
as a challenge. When asked if respondents had a dedicated budget for mental
health and wellbeing programmes in their business, 55 per cent said no. When
it comes to implementing employee mental health initiatives, employers cited
the biggest pressures as time, cost and resources. Communication and awareness
is crucial in managing the successful support of individuals who need to know
that help is available.

**Have your say**

At Paydata we ensure employers offer competitive salary and benefits packages,
benchmarking competitors and the wider market. We also define roles within
companies, providing a framework for pay systems to drive career progression
and deliver the business strategy. [Register
here](https://www.paydata.co.uk/stay-up-to-date/) to take part in our next
survey in spring and receive the full report. Or [let us know your
thoughts](https://www.paydata.co.uk) on the issues that have shaped your 2019.

# Developing positive workplace cultures

[Home](http://hrnews.co.uk) » [HR News](http://hrnews.co.uk/category/hr-news/)
» Developing positive workplace cultures

Posted on Sep 3, 2019

As the world of work and business continues to evolve, attracting, retaining
and developing the right employees has always been an important factor for
business success, but why has it become the latest “trend” in the HR world?

![](http://hrnews.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/Happy-Meeting-2.png)

Positive culture – positive employees?

A positive company culture is no longer seen as a desirable element within our
organisations, in many cases it is now seen as an essential. With so many
changes happening within our workplaces, it is therefore increasingly
important to consider how employees are managed and developed. Some factors
are more obvious, such as influences from changing technology, organisations
need to ensure that employees are equipped with the right skills so that they
are aligned with the organisation’s aspirations. This is so that they can gain
a competitive edge in their industries and achieve success in their respective
markets.

A large part of this success and having that competitive edge can be
attributed to the culture of the organisation which is one of the reasons why
the topic is now in the spotlight. Creating a positive culture is no longer
about free fruit Tuesdays, the annual pay increase or the Christmas bonus,
whilst they may be lovely gestures, they are simply not enough to hold the
levels of engagement expected by organisations, nor is it proven to achieve
employee loyalty. As the world of work has changed and as different
generations are now working together, employees are all driven by different
things and the desirable elements that employees seek when selecting an
employer are flexibility, meaningful work and autonomy, creating a sense of
balance within their daily lives.

Another workplace fad?

It is easy to view organisational culture as a fad, but having regular
conversations about conflict at work with my clients, I can say first hand
that I do not believe that it is a fad and can be backed up with evidence.
Recently, Robert Half conducted a survey and established that a third of
jobseekers would reject their dream job if the organisational culture was a
negative one.

The role of HR

HR are often seen as the drivers behind workplace cultures, but it is in fact
everyone’s responsibility to ensure that the working environment is a happier
place to be. One of the strongest engagement tools that can be used is the
organisations line managers, they know their people better than anyone and
they are then enabled to not only manage their employees effectively, but they
are in a position where they can win hearts and minds. Additionally, they can
provide a view to senior management in order to obtain support and put
employee wellbeing as a priority. It is important to keep in mind that this
doesn’t happen overnight, it takes a great deal of trust from senior
management and from the employees, so the people in the middle need to be able
to use their knowledge and skills to influence at both sides. It takes
consistent effort and investment, which is sadly not often seen a business
priority, but if these elements are in place, this can help to create a
positive working environment for everybody.

Trust

Let’s face it, the fundamentals of any employment relationship are based upon
trust. Trust is also a confident relationship with the unknown, it enables us
to feel comfortable with the unfamiliar. Being vulnerable is at the heart of
trust and that is why it is incredibly damaging and hurtful when it breaks
down.

Over the next few years, we will certainly experience significant changes as
we embrace new ways of working, without trust, this can potentially create a
toxic culture within which energy that could be spent on productivity is
actually spent on office politics and negative behaviours, which results in
wasted time, money and energy which could be better spent elsewhere.

Authenticity

The authenticity of business leaders, accountability, ethical working
practices, empowerment, fair management all have an important part to play in
promoting a positive organisational culture. By creating an environment within
which employees feel empowered and working with purpose increases productivity
and gets employees working to their full potential. Additionally, it isn’t a
secret that a key to attracting and retaining the best talent is by giving
employees purpose and making them feel valued. By being transparent and
starting with small actions, this can be a great starting point to creating a
positive culture.

One size does NOT fit all!

There is no one size fits all when it comes to effective leadership, however,
there are many ways to encourage a positive culture through the workplace. By
being open minded, line managers can identify the expectations and needs of
employees, they can then tailor their approach to their employees. If managers
are responsive to the changing environments and combine this with a flexible
approach, this can enable effective management of negative behaviours quickly
and establish new ways of working. Again, trust has an important part to play
as the new ways of working are established, this may include delegation of
tasks which many people are generally uncomfortable with.

Development

Management and leadership skills are difficult to find and should never be
taken for granted, training and ongoing support through initiatives such as
mentoring enable managers to become successful leaders. If organisations fail
to support managers appropriately, they risk setting them up for a fall
especially in cases of promotion, the employee may be great at what they do,
but are they then promoted for that fact into a role beyond the scope of their
capability? By investing in development, this can avoid this common mistake
made by too many employers.

# Why financial wellbeing starts with improving pay and reward awareness

[Home](http://hrnews.co.uk) » [HR News](http://hrnews.co.uk/category/hr-news/)
» Why financial wellbeing starts with improving pay and reward awareness

Posted on Jan 6, 2020

_John Petter, CEO, Zellis_

According to recent research from the CIPD, a quarter of HR professionals
believe poor financial wellbeing is a major cause of workplace stress. This
stress damages employee motivation and productivity, as well as – by extension
– business output and the customer experience.

![](http://hrnews.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/money2.jpg)

Poor financial wellbeing is a result of a toxic combination of an
underperforming economy, slowing wage growth, peak levels of household debt,
stagnant savings habits, and – of course – low levels of financial literacy.

There’s a misconception that the employer’s main role in this situation should
be to help alleviate the consequences of poor financial wellbeing, like debt,
rather than address the root causes.

But our own survey of UK employees indicates that a more beneficial approach
to supporting financial wellbeing is to start with the basics: using education
to build financial literacy, especially as it relates to the all-important
details found on the traditional payslip.

**Understanding the awareness gap**

Let’s take a closer look at some of our findings.

We found that less than half (44%) of UK employees are offered financial
literacy education. At face value this might not be too surprising; after all,
most people don’t view money and personal finance as traditional topics of
discussion within the workplace.

However, if we take the viewpoint that pay and reward is in fact the central
transaction between an employer and its employees, it’s easier to see a
logical role for organisations to support their staff in improving their
financial literacy. It’s a key example of making those employees feel valued
and rewarded for the work that they do, beyond just processing the payroll.

It’s also a crucial way to build trust, especially with faith in banks and
traditional financial institutions starting to diminish. At the same time,
there is a clear line to be drawn between employer-led financial literacy
initiatives and providing access to regulated financial advice – the latter
being something which businesses should steer well clear of.

Judging by our research, there’s a clear need to explain how fundamental
concepts such as tax, benefits and pension contributions, actually work. The
majority (58%) of employees admit that they don’t fully understand their
payslips, while only a quarter (24%) check their statement every month.

This lack of awareness extends to benefits, with nearly a third (32%) saying
they don’t have enough information about the choices available to them, as
well as pensions, with a quarter saying they aren’t clear on their different
options.

In support of this, the CIPD also found that less than a quarter (24%) of HR
professionals think their employees have the knowledge to make the right
reward and benefit choices to meet their financial needs. As a result, they
can’t take full advantage of the attractive employment packages that many
organisations offer today.

So employers must do more to close this information gap. Employees indicate
that this would have a positive impact both on their wellbeing and their
relationship with their organisation:

  * 63% said they would feel more looked after 
  * 33% said they would be more loyal 
  * 31% said they would feel less stressed about money issues

But what steps can employers take to make this happen?

**Develop financial education programmes:** One of the most straightforward
methods would be to develop financial education programmes. These can be
managed by an internal expert or an external provider. The content of these
programmes should cater to a range of ages and experiences, covering
everything from how to understand a basic payslip and how to use certain
benefits, to the complexities of the tax system and how different pension
options work.

One might also consider it to be a responsibility of the organisation to
inform employees of their eligibility to receive certain state benefits.
Hundreds of thousands of low-wage employees don’t claim benefits they are
entitled to do today – and these are the people who end up in-work, but
suffering severe financial stress. Correcting this could make a significant
difference to wellbeing, especially for workers in low wage jobs that may not
be aware they are entitled to receive Universal Credit, for example.

**Engage employees with benefit choices:** The benefits package on offer plays
a huge part in differentiating an organisation in the eyes of employees,
impacting on both talent acquisition and retention. However, encouraging
uptake of benefits can be a struggle and organisations sometimes find that
this area of HR investment doesn’t generate the return they were hoping for.

This may be put down to three main reasons:

  1. A lack of awareness of what benefits are available
  2. A lack of knowledge about how to use the benefits
  3. A lack of relevant and useful benefits. 

All of the reasons point to a clear solution, which is to engage with
employees throughout the process of designing a benefits strategy. Gathering
feedback directly from employees improves the organisation’s understanding of
which benefits are the most useful and relevant. At the same time it helps
build benefits awareness and knowledge for employees – something which can
also be achieved by providing a ‘total rewards statement’ as part of, or
alongside, the traditional payslip.

We shouldn’t forget that base pay remains one of, if not the most important
reasons for an individual to join an organisation. But once pay rates are
deemed to be satisfying and fair, employers must focus on communicating the
intangible elements of the employment package in order to boost recruitment,
retention and productivity.

**Improve access to HR systems:** A crucial part of improving financial
awareness and wellbeing in the workplace is making sure employees have hassle-
free access to information held in HR systems, especially with the increased
use of ‘self-service’. All too often employees have to contend with multiple
logins across multiple different platforms, which can be frustrating and may
put them off trying even the simplest of activities, such as checking their
payslip and pension contributions.

Similar problems can occur if the user interface is outdated and clunky, or if
the systems can’t be easily accessed on mobile devices. Remember that modern
employees typically conduct a lot of life-admin, such as updating their bank
details, outside of work and on-the-go.

Prioritising investment in HR systems that meet the expectations of today’s
workforce for agile, easy to use, consumer-grade technology is essential. It
helps employees feel more aware and in control of their pay and rewards, and –
as a result – more secure in their financial situation.

In 2020, worrying about money will be more stressful to employees than their
work or relationships. Our research shows the hugely positive impact improving
financial literacy at work can have for all involved. Improved loyalty, higher
employee engagement and less stress means better customer experiences, lower
costs and higher productivity.

# Relationships in the Workplace

[Home](http://hrnews.co.uk) » [HR News](http://hrnews.co.uk/category/hr-news/)
» Relationships in the Workplace

Posted on Nov 7, 2019

McDonald’s Chief Executive Steve Easterbrook has recently been dismissed after
it emerged that he had a [relationship with an
employee](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-50283720).

![](http://hrnews.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/couple.jpg)

This has sparked much debate over the appropriateness of workplace personal
relationships and how employers should address the issue in practice.

Employers should be mindful that they may face claims for discrimination
should they be putting people at a disadvantage due to certain protected
characteristics, for example, sex or sexual orientation. Should a female be
treated differently to a male in similar circumstances, then she may have a
claim and this could prove costly for your business as our article on the
[cost of discrimination highlights](https://www.hr-24.co.uk/articles/can-you-
afford-the-cost-of-workplace-discrimination-claim/). Employers should deal
sensitively and even-handedly with both partners in these circumstances and
our expert HR consultants are on hand to advise you on dealing with such
matters.

Of further concern is the balance that must be struck by an employer in
dealing with personal relationships in work, whilst allowing the employee
their right to a private life as is afforded under Article 8 of the European
Charter on Human Rights: Right to respect for private and family life. An
outright ban on romantic involvement at work is likely to be considered
disproportionate, however, a requirement that staff are to disclose
relationships, in order that the employer may take steps to avoid any
conflicts of interest, may be considered proportionate.

In many cases, a personal relationship between staff will not interfere with
work and it is important that staff are respected to conduct themselves
professionally. There should be mutual trust and confidence in the employment
relationship; should an employer fundamentally breach this implied term; they
may face a claim of constructive unfair dismissal.

However, personal relationships at work have the potential to be a serious
management concern and a policy to address the matter is advisable. The
following issues may be of serious management concern:

  * Legal risks regarding discrimination and harassment
  * Risk to the confidentiality of business information
  * Actual or perceived bias in recruitment/promotion/appraisals/discipline, especially when staff in a personal relationship are directly reporting to or subordinate to the other
  * Adverse impacts on team dynamics and team morale

Of considerable concern will be subordinate personal relationships in the
workplace and an employer may wish to include, as a matter of policy, that
staff must inform HR of such relationships should they arise. Some employers
may decide to agree a plan with the couple

to minimise the impact of the personal relationship on the business. This is
likely to involve one or both of the partners transferring where possible or
removing the responsibility of the manager in certain circumstances. However,
each case must be dealt with on the facts and there are considerable risks in
making such changes. As such, it is important that you seek specialist advice
on the issue.

If you have any concerns or would like free advice on this topic or any
employment law matter, please call 0800 015 2519 or register for free access
to [HR24 Dashboard](https://www.hr-24.co.uk/register/).
